Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the channel will further our understanding of the channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the channel. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the risk of food shortages in many regions. We quantify the magnitude of this risk for maize production and trade, the most important staple crop worldwide. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values in most major maize-producing and -exporting countries. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and to a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that species differed in the proportion of their diets made up of grasses, and that species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption had the greatest overlap in diets. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. It is established by the most aggressive and competitive individuals, who are able to maintain their position in the hierarchy. We show that high-anxious rats are less likely to become dominant than low-anxious rats. We also show that high-anxious rats exhibit reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in reward processing, and that this is associated with a low probability to become dominant. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and that it is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin content of red blood cells is determined by the expression of the globin genes, which are under the control of the HNF4A and BCL11A transcription factors. Here we show that the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway is involved in the regulation of globin gene expression. We also show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and plays a role in the regulation of hemoglobin expression.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. We report here that the inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by sustained activation of mTORC1 and the transcriptional induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central regulator of lipid metabolism. In addition, we show that the induction of ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells is accompanied by the development of stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1)-mediated lipogenesis. Thus, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy. This approach may be particularly effective in cancer cells with hyperactive PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling, such as those with loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), a common event in human cancer. This study may also provide a new perspective on the development of ferroptosis as a therapeutic target for cancer. (Read more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated adaptive management, and was the first plan to use a land-ownership map to guide management. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but that the policy failed to halt the decline of older forests. This failure is partly due to the continued expansion of clearcutting on private lands, which is not covered by the NWFP. The NWFP is now 25 years old, and it is time to evaluate its success. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, since the evolution of pathogens is a very fast process. Therefore, computational approaches are essential tools to this end, since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study is a proof of concept that rational design can be successfully applied to antibiotic discovery. The results of this study are expected to contribute to the development of new antibiotics. We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems.

Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning, compared with reading a printed book. The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is dependent on the time of its ablation. We show that ablation of CTLA-4 in adult mice results in a spectrum of autoimmunity, whereas congenital deficiency is protective. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We reconstructed the phylogeny of beetles, estimated the timing of beetle diversification, and traced the evolution of genes enabling specialized plant feeding. Our results suggest that the origin of beetles is linked to the origin of plants, and that the evolution of specialized plant feeding in beetles is linked to the evolution of genes enabling the digestion of plant cell walls.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs) that have the potential to evade the efficacy of approved vaccines and antibodies. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatment strategies.

Language is a uniquely human ability, enabling communication and thought. The brain’s language comprehension system is a complex and poorly understood part of the mind. Here, we show that the most accurate deep learning models of language comprehension also predict brain responses to language in humans. These results provide computational and neuroscientific support for the idea that predictive processing is a fundamental mechanism in the brain’s language comprehension system.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is still not clear how to prove its stability. We prove that there are cases where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs) with great approximation qualities, but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a fundamental paradox, and we show that it is due to the fact that the stability of NNs is not a well-behaved property. We introduce a theory of classification for the existence of algorithms that compute stable NNs. We prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major public health crisis. It is also a major source of scientific and public debate. In this context, it is important to critically assess the scientific evidence that underpins public health policy. This is particularly true for the claim that the pandemic is caused by a lack of understanding of exponential growth. We show that this claim is based on an experiment that was flawed in its design and analysis. We also show that the experiment’s critical design flaws were not recognized at the time of its publication. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon. We found that M. lepromatosis is closely related to the MRCA of the two bacteria, and that it is still capable of causing disease in the nervous system. This suggests that the two leprosy bacteria have been in a state of coevolution for a long time.

Entanglement and entropy are central concepts in quantum mechanics. They are the key ingredients for the description of the quantum state of a system, and they are the basis for the description of the thermodynamic properties of a system. However, the dynamics of these quantities is not trivial to compute. In particular, the dynamics of entanglement in interacting systems is still an open problem. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is a major step forward in the understanding of the dynamics of entanglement in interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing, and there is a need for a vaccine that can be used in mass vaccination programs. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is highly attenuated and can be used in mass vaccination programs. This vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. The furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. This vaccine candidate is able to protect hamsters from the disease caused by the wild-type virus and is able to reduce the weight loss upon challenge with the wild-type virus. This vaccine candidate is therefore a promising candidate for use in mass vaccination programs. (Show more)

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that of rodent transmission. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which is supported by the mortality curves of nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results challenge the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats, and suggest that human ectoparasites were primary vectors during the Second Pandemic. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to prevent future outbreaks.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known driver of animal behavior and cognition. However, the evolution of brain numbers, which are the basic units of information processing, has been neglected. Here, we show that the evolution of brain numbers is a major driver of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) in mitochondria has been the subject of intense investigation for the past 15 y. The current view is that TRAP1 is an anticancer target, but this view is based on the assumption that TRAP1 is a single-target drug target. We show that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator, and that its function is context dependent. We also show that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. Severing is a critical process in many biological contexts, including cell motility, cell division, and cell morphogenesis. However, the molecular mechanism of ADF severing is not well understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to actin filaments and induces severing when filaments are under mechanical stress. We propose that this mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of severing in cells and for the design of new drugs that target ADF.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation and greater hunger and desire for food and food-approach behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by insulin.

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. Our work suggests that emotional contagion is not limited to in-person interaction, and that nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. The presence of RNA modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) is a common phenomenon, but their functional significance is not well understood. We show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in an mRNA codon can modestly alter translation speed and the products of translation. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in coding regions of mRNAs may be a mechanism by which the ribosome can adapt to mRNA sequences that are not perfectly complementary. This may be particularly important in the context of translation of noncoding RNAs, which are often not perfectly complementary to their target mRNAs. Our findings may also have implications for the translation of retrotransposons, which are often modified with Ψ. Our work provides a framework for understanding the functional significance of mRNA modifications and their impact on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of aquatic mammals. We use a model of the energetic constraints of the aquatic environment to show that the evolution of larger body sizes is driven by the aquatic environment and is constrained by the aquatic environment.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. We show that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. In bacteria, this process is often mediated by chemosensory systems that respond to chemical signals in the environment. In this study, we demonstrate that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense the surface on which it is growing. This process is mediated by a specific type of chemosensory system, which is unique to P. aeruginosa and is involved in the regulation of a large number of virulence factors. Our findings provide insight into the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and the role of pili in bacterial motility and virulence. They also have implications for the development of new strategies to combat bacterial infections.

The presence of pesticides in surface waters is a global concern. However, the extent of pesticide contamination is poorly understood because of a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. We provide a global metaanalysis of the presence of pesticides in surface waters. Our results show that the presence of pesticides in surface waters is widespread and that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. This study highlights the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the ecology of emerging infectious diseases. The SARS-CoV-2 virus has been shown to circulate in a variety of animal species, including free-living animals. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in Iowa, USA. We also show that the virus is circulating at high levels during the winter, when deer are most active. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology and evolution of emerging infectious diseases. The proliferation of large dams in developing countries is a major concern. This paper examines the reasons for the growth of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. We also propose solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms underlying the development of these pathologies are not fully understood, but are thought to be related to the activation of the immune system. Here, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type affected in AD, are capable of producing a variety of immune factors, which are not expressed by neighboring glial cells. We also demonstrate that the production of these factors is dependent on the accumulation of soluble Aβ in the cell. These findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a significant contributor to the development of AD. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation remains elusive. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was practiced there as early as the fourth century B.C.E. This is the earliest known evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the folding pathway is not known for most proteins. The pathway is important for understanding the role of the protein in the cell and the stability of the protein. Here we describe the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, at high structural resolution. The protein folds through a native-like intermediate in a slow step. The intermediate is a distinct conformation that is not present in the native state. The intermediate is a common step in the folding of many proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism by which bacteria can adapt to that stress. However, the cellular conditions that enable this accumulation are also those that inactivate the predominant decapping enzyme in bacteria, ApaH. Here, we show that the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to decapt decapped RNA, is the predominant decapping enzyme in Escherichia coli cells experiencing disulfide stress. We also show that, in the presence of Np4, RppH decaps Np4-capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decapt other 5′ termini. This unique manner of decapping Np4-capped RNAs and the differential impact it has on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is depleted in sepsis and that this depletion is associated with the development of immunosuppression. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and decreasing the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the outcome of sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all the organisms that inhabit the planet. It is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of the biomass of different taxa is still lacking. Here, we assemble the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the ocean. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They are essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a baseline for future studies on the impact of human activities on the biosphere.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

This is achieved by strain engineering, which is a promising approach to tune the properties of materials. Our findings can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for specific applications. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the sperm proteome, and that these contributions are critical for supporting sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work is a significant step forward in our understanding of the molecular basis of reproductive success. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the subject of intense study for the past 20 y. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study overcomes this barrier, and provides a database of over 45,000 unique virus taxa, with a median completeness of 80%. We find that many of the strongest known associations between viruses and disease are found in this database.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in climate models due to the complexity of the process. Observations of aerosol and cloud properties are challenging for current remote-sensing techniques. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of the early Earth has been the subject of intense debate. The isotopic evidence suggests that the oceans cooled from 70 ± 15 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C. However, this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present a method for reconstructing the temperature of ancient surface environments based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. The malaria parasite must invade the red blood cell (RBC) to complete its life cycle. The invasion process is a complex event, and the mechanisms by which the parasite interacts with the host cell are poorly understood. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, which may facilitate invasion. We show that the parasite binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface and that this interaction leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell. These changes in the RBC are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This work suggests that the parasite primes the RBC surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The impact of environmental factors on influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides mechanistic insights into the impact of environmental factors on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic phrases as it processes a sentence. However, there is no direct evidence that the brain actually does this. Here, we show that, in the left hemisphere, high-gamma power increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is applied equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity, and it is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with the idea that the brain is constantly searching for the most efficient representation of the incoming language stream.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer therapy. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2. We show here that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently in different tissues, and that this differential regulation is important for the proper functioning of the pathway.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the search for new treatments is ongoing. Here we describe a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces eating in sated mice, and that this effect is blocked by lesions of the lateral hypothalamus or the dopamine system. We also show that this circuit is necessary for the effect of stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus. Finally, we show that this circuit is not involved in the mechanisms that govern hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of a circuit that may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the primary limiting nutrient for plant growth and productivity. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and their bacteria would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in a sustainable and efficient manner. Here, we have developed a system that allows for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley. This system is based on the production of a signaling molecule by the plant, which is then sensed by the bacteria. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also represents a significant step forward in the development of a synthetic biology platform for the control of nitrogen-fixing symbioses. This platform could be used to develop a range of applications, including the development of sustainable agriculture systems. (Show more)

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured hearing organ that is not constrained by the body. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of the air particles and remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave. The spider can also adjust and regenerate the web according to its needs. This study provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of hearing function in spiders. It also provides a new way to study extended and regenerative sensing and design novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The lack of affordable vaccines for low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) remains a major barrier to global containment. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-volume microbial production. This variant exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, and antibodies raised against it exhibit heterotypic binding to the RBD from two recently reported variants of concern. Presentation of the variant on a designed VLP also reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD variant may be a promising candidate for a subunit vaccine for LMICs. This work provides a proof-of-concept for the design of a subunit vaccine for LMICs, which may be a critical step toward global containment of COVID-19. (Show more)

Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor of neural crest-derived tissues in children. The molecular mechanisms underlying the development of this disease are not fully understood. Here, we show that zebrafish ALK-like (DrALK) proteins are activated by a family of secreted ligands and that this signaling is required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish eye. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK-like receptors in the development of neural crest-derived tissues and suggest a role for these receptors in human diseases. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for some of the most devastating pandemics in human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have provided a glimpse into its early evolution and ecology, but the number of genomes are too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. These data provide a more complete picture of the formative years of plague. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. Implications for public health and public policy are discussed.

The management of agricultural systems can have profound effects on the quantity and distribution of soil organic carbon (SOC). However, the efficacy of different management practices in sequestering SOC on grassland-derived Mollisols remains highly uncertain. We found that the management of annual cropping systems on a Mollisol in the United States can have a profound effect on SOC storage. Compared to conventional continuous maize monocropping with annual tillage, systems with reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, or manure addition did not increase total SOC storage or mineral-associated SOC, whereas perennial pastures managed with rotational grazing accumulated more SOC and mineral-associated SOC (18 to 29% higher) than all annual cropping systems after 29 y of management. These results highlight the key role of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses from wildlife reservoirs to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread to humans. We validated the framework using a large dataset of viruses discovered in wildlife. The resulting database, SpillOver, is a living, interactive tool that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a critical resource for the global community to better understand and mitigate the risk of emerging viral threats. This work is a step forward in the fight against zoonotic disease.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the mechanisms that underlie this trait are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a similar trait in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely to be favored by selection. This work provides a better understanding of the evolution of nectar color and its role in plant–pollinator interactions. (Show more)

The genetic landscape of Europe is a complex mosaic of genetic contributions from different parts of the world. However, the processes that shaped this landscape are still poorly understood. Here we present a case study of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived in the late 5th/early 6th century. Our results indicate that they had a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The emergence of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) in humans has caused ∼36% fatality. The virus shares a common receptor with bat coronaviruses, but the differences in their spike proteins suggest that the adaptation of MERS-CoV to human cells may contribute to the enhanced pathogenesis of MERS-CoV in humans. Here, we show that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, are different from those of MERS-CoV. These results suggest that the adaptation of MERS-CoV to use human cells for cross-species transmissions may be due to the differences in the spike proteins of MERS-CoV and bat coronaviruses. This study provides insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the risk of bat coronaviruses to human health. (Show more)

We found that mNGS is a powerful tool for the rapid detection of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This approach can be used to identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study highlights the importance of mNGS in resource-scarce settings and the need for coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance. The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is critical for every aspect of lagging strand replication. However, the stability of the human pol δ holoenzyme has never been determined. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is a key determinant of the rate of lagging strand synthesis and the fidelity of replication. This work provides a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and the implications for the replication of the lagging strand. This article is protected by copyright. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. The hypothesis that life arose from prebiotic RNA molecules is one of the most popular answers to this question. However, the experimental evidence for this hypothesis is weak. Here, we describe a method for the in vitro evolution of RNA polymerase ribozymes that can replicate RNA molecules, thereby providing a means to test the RNA world hypothesis in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the efficacy of tocilizumab in severe and critical COVID-19 patients was assessed. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately, and the mortality was reduced. Therefore, tocilizumab is an effective treatment for severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic. The ability to regulate copper levels is therefore critical for survival. In this work, we demonstrate that the xan BGC of Aspergillus fumigatus is involved in the regulation of copper levels. The xan BGC is found in several filamentous fungi, suggesting that this is a widespread mechanism for the regulation of copper homeostasis. This work provides a new perspective on the role of natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the interactions between fungi and bacteria. (Show more)

Frost is a major environmental factor that affects the performance of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. Despite their ecological and economic impact, the geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of these frost events are poorly understood. We show that the resistance strategies of trees to late-spring frosts are region-specific and that the resistance strategies of trees to late-spring frosts are changing. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of IBD is unclear. We found that IFN-γ–deficient Th17 cells were unable to induce colitis in a transfer model. Development of disease required the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells and was contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of IBD pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Our findings suggest that targeting Th17 cells may be a useful strategy for the treatment of IBD. (Read more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by the degeneration of motor neurons, which are the cells responsible for generating muscle movement. The disease is progressive, and death is usually due to respiratory failure. The disease is very difficult to model in animal models, and there are no effective treatments. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study the disease, and to screen for drugs that can alleviate the disease. This will greatly improve our ability to study the disease and develop effective treatments. (Read more)

The gut microbiota of the vector is a critical factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. Here, we show that a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, modifies the gut microbiota of the vector, the Ixodes scapularis tick, to more efficiently colonize the tick. We demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota by inducing the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the bacterial peptidoglycan cell wall, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an antibacterial protein from an arthropod vector to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector microbiome and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The presence of a pygostyle, a short tail bone, is a defining feature of modern birds. However, the earliest members of the group are poorly known, obscuring our understanding of the origin of the modern avian tail. Here, we describe a new early member of the group, Jinguofortis perplexus, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia.

We show that the stratosphere is a major contributor to climate change. This is a major discovery, because it is the first time that a feedback from the stratosphere to the troposphere has been identified. This discovery has implications for the way we think about climate change, because it means that the climate sensitivity of the Earth is likely to be larger than previously thought.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can affect its ability to blend in with its environment. In this study, we show that the color of some vertebrates can change over evolutionary time. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, which is the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The identification of factors that promote the development of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) is important for the development of new therapies. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is increased in BCSCs and is regulated by hypoxia and ALKBH5. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in response to hypoxia may promote the development of BCSCs. This study may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (Read more)

The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was difficult to tell the animal species from which it came. Here, we show that the method of extraction of the protein from the parchment surface is a simple and objective way to identify the animal species from which the parchment was made. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did find that more than one species of animal was used in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. This suggests that the production process allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment from the past. (Read more)

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is critical to understanding its cause and the dynamics of recovery. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery of the carbon cycle was not complete for ∼500 ka. These results are critical for understanding the extinction and recovery of the Permian-Triassic fossil record. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is characterized by the overactivation of the immune system, leading to the destruction of the intestinal epithelium. The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against the invasion of pathogens and the maintenance of homeostasis. The intestinal epithelium is composed of multiple cell types, including the epithelial cells, immune cells, and fibroblasts. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a new perspective on the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the human ACE2 receptor and the cellular protease TMPRSS2. We find that the receptor binding domain of the spike glycoprotein is in a more open conformation when bound to ACE2, which may facilitate virus entry. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the mutant D614G virus. (Read more)

We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in other disciplines, such as physics, geology, biology, and medicine. The chemical properties of atoms are also of great interest in the search for new materials, which is a major goal of modern science. We show that the chemical properties of atoms change with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical properties of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of these effects is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon cycle. We show that human demography, rather than climate, is the main driver of changes in global fire activity. This has important implications for the carbon cycle, as it means that climate change may not be the main driver of future warming. Our results suggest that, to mitigate climate change, we need to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, as well as the impacts of human activities, such as land use change and fire suppression.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major contributor to host health and development. However, the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of this community are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, is critical for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is delivered by host cells to the symbiotic organ just before dusk, when the organ is at its most active. The glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting metabolites to maintain a healthy symbiosis. This study provides a mechanism by which the host may regulate the composition of the gut microbiota. It also suggests that other hosts may use the provision of specific nutrients to regulate the composition of their gut microbiota. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method is motivated by the need to understand the gendered nature of violent death narratives. We show that our method can identify topics that are not captured by existing structured variables and can provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope that our method will be useful to many domains. The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were highly correlated during the 14th century, and that this correlation was not due to a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, but rather to a series of introductions, each of which was followed by a long period of adaptation of the bacterium to the local climate. Our results suggest that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were highly correlated during the 14th century, and that this correlation was not due to a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, but rather to a series of introductions, each of which was followed by a long period of adaptation of the bacterium to the local climate. This adaptation process may have been the cause of the long lag time between the introduction of the bacterium and the establishment of the disease in Europe.

Sea stars are important predators of algae and thus play a key role in the marine food web. However, they are also a valuable food source for humans and are therefore often removed from the ecosystem. In recent years, a disease has been observed that causes rapid mortality of sea stars. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is highly contagious. The virus is also present in the past museum specimens of sea stars. This suggests that the disease has been present for a long time and that it is likely to have a negative impact on the ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of new targets for therapy is urgently needed. We show here that a monoclonal antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is effective in the treatment of AML in mice. We demonstrate that the observed effects are mediated by antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and that IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling is effective in the treatment of AML. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other diseases in which IL-1 signaling is important. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern (VOCs) that have the potential to evade the efficacy of approved vaccines and antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help in the development of new antibody drug candidates to combat the ongoing pandemic. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status and condition. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative applications. We show how to transform the original crop expert assessments into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more amenable to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that this probabilistic variable can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert assessments are a valuable source of information that can be used to improve the accuracy of crop condition and yield forecasts. This is particularly important in the context of climate change, where the accuracy of crop condition and yield forecasts is critical for agricultural decision-making.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is thought to be supported by a combination of mechanisms. Here we propose a computational model of language that is based on a single mechanism: the ability to maintain information in the form of adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is not dependent on the maintenance of elevated firing rates, inhibitory feedback, or synaptic plasticity. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, because it is marked by a gradual change in the environment and the lifestyle of the organism. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key event in the evolution of plastids, is also accompanied by a gradual relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome.

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in over a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this event by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the risk of drought in SSA is increasing, and that the current drought is likely to be the first of many. This highlights the urgent need for climate change adaptation in the region. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The discovery of a naturally occurring quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb, is a significant milestone in the history of quasicrystals.

Photosynthesis is the primary process by which the biosphere captures solar energy and converts it into chemical energy. The biosynthesis of the pigments that mediate this process is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll pigments is a key step in this process. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here we describe the evolution of this reaction and its three classes. These data are important for understanding the evolution of photosynthesis and the biosynthesis of the pigments that mediate it. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of multiple sclerosis (MS), and it is well known that neuroinflammation is associated with neurodegenerative diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of neuroinflammation in MS remain unclear. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was phase specific, and the roles of apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) in neuroinflammation were cell type specific. ASK1 in microglia/macrophages was critical for the early stage of neuroinflammation, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes was critical for the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study may provide a better understanding of the pathophysiology of MS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is due to human activities. We also find that the probability of drought has increased because of the occurrence of warm conditions during dry periods. These findings have important implications for water management, ecosystem management, and wildfire risk.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the autism-risk genes and a potential target for the development of therapeutics. It also provides a framework for the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. This study is expected to contribute to the development of therapeutics for autism. This work is the first to our knowledge to report on the prevalence of negativity biases in a large, representative sample of the world’s population. It also provides the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, and it highlights considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein ORAI1, associated with congenital bleeding and myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in Drosophila is dependent on the presence of a defined subset of neurons and is dependent on the presence of a defined subset of neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the presence of a defined subset of neurons. Finally, we show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on the presence of a defined subset of neurons. These results demonstrate that the spread of aggregates is a highly specific process that is dependent on the presence of a defined subset of neurons. This work provides a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases is well established. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection by selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The findings also provide a deeper understanding of the role of the submandibular salivary gland in the immune function of bats and the potential for the submandibular salivary gland to be used as a reservoir for emerging infectious diseases. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it is effective in cancer cell lines. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that formate is a potent inhibitor of glycine import in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.
