Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. We show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, these proteins are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable protein hypothesis may provide a unifying framework for understanding the pathogenesis of ALS and other neurodegenerative disorders. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We expect that the results will be of interest to researchers in many areas, including atom optics, photonic crystals, quantum information, and many-body physics.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the exact ecological conditions under which the first flowering plants evolved are still debated. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia, a very early flowering plant from the Cretaceous. Our results suggest that the early flowering plants were aquatic plants, similar to Ceratophyllum, and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 thousand years ago) and show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is dated to ∼12.6 thousand years ago, and we find that the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. These results emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Read more)

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily over the last century, but the rate of rise accelerated in the last two decades. This study shows that the acceleration is due to the Earth’s warming and is consistent with the IPCC’s projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain is not only more common in midlife than in old age, but that it is also more common in the less educated than in the more educated. This pattern is seen across birth cohorts, and it is not explained by changes in occupation or obesity. It is a mystery of American pain.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this defining species. The results highlight the importance of the crystallographic waters in the active site and the role of the catalytic lysine side chain in the reaction pathway. The study also highlights the importance of the active site environment in determining the substrate specificity of the enzyme. These results are expected to have a significant impact on the study of enzyme mechanisms. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral that inhibits the replication of several RNA viruses, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their communities. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is critical for the maintenance of a symbiotic relationship between a squid and its luminescent bacterium. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is active and the bacterium is producing light. These results suggest that the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery may be regulated by the host to maintain the stability of the symbiosis. This work provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the regulation of animal–microbe interactions. (Read more)

Suspension rates are rising in the United States and elsewhere. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can be sustained. The findings have implications for the design of effective school discipline policies and for the quality of teacher–student relationships.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of DNA. The molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis are still unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on the transcriptional fidelity of RNA polymerase II (pol II). We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions have distinct effects on the transcriptional fidelity of pol II. The minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion is error-free, whereas the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion leads to a dominant error-prone route. For the N3-EtdT lesion, which disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes severe pneumonia. To cause infection, MERS-CoV must bind to cell receptors and fuse with the cell membrane. The virus uses two sequential proteases to activate the fusion reaction, but the mechanisms that control these sequential cleavages are unknown. We found that the first cleavages of MERS-CoV S proteins are required for infection of human lung-derived cells, but not for infection of other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are important determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also responsible for a large share of obesity and diet-related disease. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large-scale catering operation can have a large impact on meal selection, without having a large impact on overall meal sales. This suggests that simple changes to catering practices could have a large impact on population health and the environment. The results also suggest that it may be possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets without the need for complex interventions. This is an important contribution to the literature on the potential for nudging to improve population health.

The cell surface is the interface between the cell and its environment. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the cell surface proteome is the set of proteins that are exposed to the extracellular space. We have developed a method to measure the surface proteome of cells, and applied it to characterize the surfaceome of a panel of oncogene-expressing breast epithelial cells. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of the proteins are harmonized by common biological themes. We complement the surfaceome data with a method to measure the glycoproteome, and find that oncogenes have a profound effect on the glycoproteome. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a widespread call for expanding voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. However, the effects of vote-by-mail are not well understood. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal effects on electoral outcomes.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with a high mortality rate and a lack of effective treatments. The role of the viral accessory protein ORF8 in the disease severity of COVID-19 is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2, and we hypothesize that it may be important for the immune evasion and/or evasion of interferon responses that are associated with the severity of COVID-19. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutics to combat the pandemic. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the mechanisms underlying this condition are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats and that this effect is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF, acting on its receptor CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying hypoxic cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from data. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In this paper we describe a challenge that arises when we have a large dataset and we are interested in finding associations in that dataset. We describe a way to address this challenge, and we illustrate its use in a number of common statistical methods.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of organs. In this study, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of vascular networks in vivo. This finding provides a new strategy for the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

The discovery of the “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has led to the identification of their physiological ligands. However, the physiological role of these ligands and their link to the development of specific tissues remains to be elucidated. Here, we show that the zebrafish ortholog of Ltk, which is a physiological ligand of augmentor, plays a critical role in the development of the eye and the pigment system. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for future studies on the role of augmentor ligands in the development of other tissues. (Read more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular basis of T2D is well known, the treatment of T2D is still challenging. In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Our study provides a potential target for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and is sequence dependent. The interaction we identified involves regions not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A virus. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and might lead to the development of new strategies to control influenza virus infections. (Read more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular cells. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP) and transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the disturbed flow-induced activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes of vascular cells. Our results demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced activation of proatherosclerotic phenotypes and atherogenesis. It also provides a potential target for the development of athero-protective therapeutic strategies. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they are now a major threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to carbon emissions. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades, and climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity. However, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of reducing wildfire risk to people and ecosystems, and the need for policies to reduce the risk of wildfire ignitions. (Less)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne pathogen that has recently emerged as a cause of severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of ZIKV infection and disease are not fully understood, and there is a need for a better understanding of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the within-host dynamics of ZIKV are consistent with the known properties of the virus and the disease. We also provide estimates of the parameters of the model, which can be used to guide future experimental studies. This work provides a framework for future studies of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection and disease. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a widespread phenomenon that is considered a key indicator of the health of coral reefs. However, the mechanisms underlying the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic and molecular responses of the coral host to heat stress are secondary to the altered cycling of nutrients within the coral–algal symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress increases the demand for energy, which is met by the degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that separates the host from the environment. In the absence of tumorigenesis, the epithelium is maintained in a healthy state by a delicate balance between the activity of the epithelium and the microbiome. We show that the loss of tumor suppression in Drosophila leads to the development of intestinal tumors, which in turn trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium and a dysbiotic microbiome. The dysregulated microbiome, in turn, triggers a regenerative response in the tumor, leading to a vicious cycle. Our work identifies a mechanism that can be targeted to restore homeostasis in the intestinal epithelium and prevent the development of cancer. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. Chemotherapy is an important component of the treatment of breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous. We find that the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, which enhances the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). We also find that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab, which inhibits the binding of ROR1 to its ligands, suppresses the expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduces activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impairs the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The timing of the Mount Takahe volcanic eruptions and their impact on climate is poorly constrained. We used high-resolution measurements of halogen isotopes in ice cores to document the start of the Mount Takahe eruptions in 17.7 ka, and we found that the eruptions coincided with a rapid acceleration in deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere. We show that the Mount Takahe eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which likely caused a series of climate changes in the Southern Hemisphere and beyond. These changes are consistent with the modern ozone hole over Antarctica, and they plausibly link the Mount Takahe eruptions to the onset of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation ∼17.7 ka. This study provides a unique perspective on the role of volcanism in climate change. (Less)

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our map can be used to improve fishery management and protect the benefits that rivers provide to people and wildlife.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a critical feature of the adult nervous system. In mammals, however, the CNS is incapable of regenerating after injury, and the regeneration capacity of the PNS is limited. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult C. elegans nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of novel genes that regulate regeneration in the adult nervous system. Moreover, our study suggests that the ability to regenerate is a conserved feature of the adult nervous system, and that the mechanisms that regulate regeneration are evolutionarily conserved.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous DNA sequences during the process of meiosis. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity and the proper functioning of the genome. The distribution of recombination across the genome is a fundamental property of the genome, and it is thought to be conserved across species. However, the details of the distribution of recombination across the genome are not well understood. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the control of cognitive and behavioral functions. The present study provides a method to identify and characterize the resting state organization of the brain, based on metabolic imaging. This method can be used to identify the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. We report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) modification. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This discovery is important for understanding the function of NAD+ in the cell and the evolution of the eukaryotic transcriptome. It also provides a model for the evolution of new modifications. The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control could prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of this therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci persist for several years during the follow-up of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (EDIC Study) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up of the DCCT.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with the presence of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in these subjects, which may be involved in the development of the gut barrier alteration. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The production of volatile compounds is a key feature of fruit ripening, and the biosynthesis of these compounds is of interest for both flavor improvement and the development of new analytical tools. Here we describe the biosynthesis of a group of nitrogenous volatile compounds in tomato fruit, which are absent in the closely related species of the tomato clade. This work provides a foundation for the development of new tools for the study of tomato ripening and the improvement of tomato flavor. (Read more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning, and the need to consider the thermal tolerance of species when predicting the impacts of climate change.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large number of neurons that fire in a place-dependent manner, and the precise arrangement of these neurons is critical for understanding the function of MEC. However, the anatomical organization of these neurons has been difficult to study because of the small field of view and low spatial resolution of previous imaging methods. Here, we developed a portable two-photon microscope that allows mice to freely explore an open field. We used this microscope to study the spatial organization of neurons in MEC and found that grid cells, which are critical for place learning, are anatomically distinct from other neurons. These results provide a foundation for understanding the function of MEC. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a large number of genes and environmental cues. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This is a unique means of flowering regulation, which is likely to be important for the synchronization of flowering of host and parasite.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The disease is associated with the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, which is the primary target of the nigral system. However, the disease also affects the nigral system, which is the only known pathway that innervates the dopamine neurons. Here, we show that the nigral system is composed of three functionally distinct subsystems. We also show that the loss of dopamine neurons is associated with the loss of dopamine-containing neurons in the striosome–dendron bouquets, which are specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Our findings suggest that the dopamine-containing nigral system is more complex than previously thought and that the disease is associated with the loss of these specialized integrative units. This may have implications for the development of treatments for Parkinson’s disease.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also responsible for maintaining a normal heart rate in response to changes in the environment. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and it is important to understand how it maintains its function. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the function of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its function in plant physiology has been debated. Although Si is known to confer resistance to abiotic stresses, its role in mediating resistance against insect herbivores has not been well documented. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by priming of the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect rice from insect herbivory. This study may lead to the development of new strategies for insect pest control. (Read more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages.

Language is a uniquely human ability that is characterized by the ability to store and integrate information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of single neurons. We show that this mechanism can support memory on multiple timescales, including milliseconds, seconds, and even minutes. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are dependent on external inputs for their survival. One of the major challenges in plant biology is the delivery of biomolecules to the plant cells. This is a major hurdle in the delivery of functional biomolecules such as RNAi molecules to the plant cells. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver RNAi molecules across the cell wall of the plant cells. We also show that the geometry of the DNA nanostructures plays a major role in the delivery of the RNAi molecules across the cell wall. This work establishes the feasibility of using DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This work also details the design parameters that are important for the delivery of the biomolecules across the cell wall. This work is expected to be useful for the plant biologists and the synthetic biologists. This work also provides a platform for the development of new strategies for the delivery of biomolecules to plants.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient inputs to lakes come from small tributaries that drain surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large water bodies, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large lakes. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to small watersheds to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This will require a better understanding of the sources and fate of nutrients in small watersheds, as well as the development of effective nutrient management strategies for these areas. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is highly selective with respect to the chemical concentrations it can access. We find that the system is biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning” of the universe to a small set of initial conditions that lead to life.

NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) are a class of autoimmune encephalitis that can cause a wide range of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic properties of the brain, which can then predispose the brain to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We also show that the same changes in the brain can also lead to seizures. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the mechanisms underlying the wide range of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities seen in NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same changes in the brain can lead to both paroxysmal EEG abnormalities and seizures, and that the same treatment may be effective for both conditions. This may help to explain why some patients respond to treatment for one condition, but not the other. These findings also suggest that the same treatment may be effective for both conditions. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. The cause of this warming is unknown, but it is likely due to a combination of natural and anthropogenic forcings. Here, we present evidence for a similar warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma. We show that this warming was caused by a massive injection of organic matter into the ocean, which led to anoxia and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. Our results provide insights into the potential for a similar warming event in the future. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation, but that most certified areas contained little residual forest when certification was granted. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in the context of other policies and actions to reduce tropical deforestation. (Less)

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is essential for the final steps of exocytosis. It is conserved across kingdoms, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major area of study. In many species, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to determine sex. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a species with multiple sex determination alleles.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that can damage photoreceptor cells. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in retinal pigment epithelial cells, promote the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly, and may lead to the development of strategies to reduce the burden of bisretinoids in the retina. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the diversity of their feeding strategies is a key component of their ecological and evolutionary success. However, the evolution of morphological specializations is often considered a dead end, as it is constrained by the need to maintain the functionality of the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialized feeding strategies is possible in cnidarians, and that the morphological changes associated with these transitions are linked to the prey type. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of predator specialization, and the role of morphological innovation in shaping present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex structure with a long evolutionary history. The fossil record of the hominin hand between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is sparse, and the evolution of the distinctive features of the modern and Neandertal hand is poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from East Africa that preserves a key derived feature of the modern and Neandertal hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the emergence of modern human-like tool use. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it is effective in cancer cell lines. We also show that the one-carbon donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that formate is a potent inhibitor of glycine import in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity for glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change and is a key contributor to climate change. However, it is also a driver of food insecurity and malnutrition, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this impact can be mitigated by the presence of forests. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in meeting food and nutrition security goals.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it is also a major cause of land degradation. The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural land, but it has also increased the weight of vehicles, which has led to the propagation of subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers. We show that the risk of subsoil compaction is now widespread over 20% of arable land, and that this risk is increasing. We also show that the weight of modern farm vehicles is now comparable to that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that the roaming of these giants may have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles.
